title: Hot Potato Debate
desc: Students pass a ball while music plays. When it stops, the holder must instantly give an argument.
steps: Play upbeat music while students pass a ball or object around the circle.
Stop the music randomly.
Display a controversial but lighthearted topic (e.g., 'Cats are better than dogs').
The student holding the object must immediately give one argument FOR or AGAINST.
Resume music immediately to keep energy high.
variation: Use 'Truth or Dare' questions instead of debate topics for a fun ice-breaker.

title: Silent Comic Strip
materials: Printed comic strips with empty speech bubbles
desc: Students fill in empty speech bubbles of a comic strip to create a coherent story silently.
steps: Distribute a comic strip with empty speech bubbles to each student.
Set a timer for 10 minutes of absolute silence.
Students must write dialogue that makes sense narratively.
After time is up, students swap comics and read their partner's story.
variation: Cut the comic panels out separately and have students rearrange them before writing.

title: Board Race
desc: Two teams relay race to the board to write words related to a topic.
steps: Divide class into two teams standing in lines.
Give the first student in each line a marker.
Shout a category (e.g., 'Animals').
Students run to the board, write one word, run back, and pass the marker.
The team with the most correct words after 2 minutes wins.
variation: Restrict words to a specific letter (e.g., Animals starting with 'B'). For ages 3-6, have them touch flashcards on the board instead of writing.

title: Two Truths & A Lie
desc: Students spot the lie among three statements about their peers.
steps: Give students 3 minutes to write down two true facts and one lie about themselves.
In small groups, one student reads their three statements.
The group can ask 3 follow-up questions to try and catch them out.
The group votes on which statement is the lie.
variation: Teacher plays first to model the activity and build rapport.

title: Running Dictation
desc: A memory and running relay game where students dictate texts found on walls.
steps: Stick short texts on walls outside the classroom or in the hallway.
Group students: assign a 'Runner', a 'Scribe', and optionally a 'Corrector'.
Runner runs to the text, memorizes a sentence, runs back, and dictates it.
Scribe writes it down. If they forget, the Runner must go back.
First group to write the text correctly wins.
variation: Swap roles halfway through the text. To encourage accuracy over pure speed, deduct points for spelling and punctuation mistakes.

title: Vocab Pictionary
desc: Drawing vocabulary words for teammates to guess.
steps: Prepare a stack of cards with vocabulary words.
One student comes to the front, picks a card.
They have 60 seconds to draw the word on the board without speaking or writing letters.
Their team must guess the word.
variation: Use 'Claymation' style where they mold the word with playdough instead of drawing.

title: Sentence Surgery
desc: Physical rearrangement of jumbled sentence parts.
steps: Prepare envelopes containing strips of paper with words from a sentence.
Give an envelope to each pair of students.
Students dump the words and rearrange them physically to form a correct sentence.
They raise their hand when they think they have 'healed' the sentence.
variation: Include one 'distractor' word that doesn't belong in the sentence.

title: Back-to-Back Drawing
desc: Describing an image to a partner who cannot see it.
steps: Pairs sit in chairs back-to-back.
Student A is given a simple picture/diagram.
Student B has a blank paper and pencil.
Student A describes the image using shapes and prepositions (e.g., 'Draw a square in the center').
Compare the drawing with the original.
variation: Use Tangram puzzles instead of drawing for a tactile version.

title: Gallery Walk
desc: Peer review activity walking around the classroom.
steps: Post student work (essays, posters, etc.) on the classroom walls.
Give every student a pack of sticky notes.
Play calm music as students walk around 'viewing the gallery'.
Students leave one compliment and one question on a sticky note for each piece.
variation: Use different colored sticky notes for different types of feedback (e.g., Pink for praise, Green for growth).

title: This or That
desc: Students choose between two options by moving to different sides of the room, explaining their choice.
steps: Ask students to stand in the middle of the room.
Present two related words or concepts (e.g., 'Apples or Bananas', or 'Summer or Winter').
Designate the left side of the room for option A and the right side for option B.
Students run to the side they prefer.
Ask random students to justify their choice in English.
variation: For older students, make the prompts moral dilemmas or debatable topics.

title: Devil's Advocate
desc: Students are forced to argue in favor of a statement they actually disagree with.
steps: Write a controversial statement on the board.
Ask students who agrees and who disagrees.
Pair up students and force them to argue the opposite of their actual belief.
Give them 5 minutes to prepare arguments.
Have pairs present their arguments to the class.
variation: Turn it into a formal mini-debate with a strict 1-minute timer for opening statements and rebuttals.

title: Stop the Bus
desc: A fast-paced vocabulary game where teams race to fill categories starting with a specific letter.
steps: Divide the class into small teams.
Draw a table on the board with 5 categories (e.g., Animal, Food, Country, Verb, Color).
Call out a random letter of the alphabet.
Teams race to write one word for each category starting with that letter.
The first team to finish yells 'Stop the Bus!'.
Review the answers. If all are correct, they win the round.
variation: Make the categories grammar-focused, like 'Irregular Verb', 'Adjective', 'Preposition'.

title: Kim's Game
desc: A classic memory game to test and reinforce new vocabulary items.
steps: Place 10-15 familiar vocabulary items on a tray.
Let the students study the tray in silence for 1 minute.
Cover the tray with a cloth.
Students must write down (or say aloud for ages 3-6) as many objects as they can remember.
Uncover the tray and count the correct answers.
variation: Instead of covering everything, secretly remove one item while their eyes are closed and ask 'What's missing?'

title: Shout Out
desc: Students shout out known English words and then use them to make the longest sentence possible.
steps: Put students into groups and tell them to make a list of all the words they know in English.
Get the groups to write the words up on the board.
Have them use the mass of words to form the longest sentence possible.
variation: Limit words to a specific category to increase the challenge.

title: Similarities
desc: Students ask each other questions to find three non-obvious things they have in common.
steps: Pair up students.
Instruct them to ask questions until they find three things they have in common.
Remind them the similarities cannot be obvious physical traits.
Model the activity by interviewing a student until you find three commonalities.
variation: Increase the number of similarities to five for advanced students.

title: The Diminishing Sentence
desc: Students build a long sentence word by word, then try to remember it as words are randomly erased.
steps: Have students add one word at a time to a basic sentence on the board, making it as long as possible.
Erase one word at a time randomly.
Have students read the full sentence back to you, including the missing words.
Continue until only a couple of words are left.
variation: Start the next class with the final remaining word and have students reconstruct the entire paragraph.

title: People Bingo
desc: Students mingle to find classmates matching specific descriptions on a bingo grid.
steps: Fill a bingo sheet grid with questions tailored to your students.
Give all students the bingo sheet.
Students mingle and ask each other questions to fill their blocks.
variation: Have students write the names in the boxes and shout 'Bingo!' when they get a full row or blackout.

title: Verbal Charades
desc: Students describe a word to the class without saying the word itself or using hand motions.
steps: Write nouns on slips of paper and put them in a hat.
Each student takes a slip and reads the word.
The student describes the word without saying it, using gestures, or making descriptive noises.
Other students guess the word.
variation: Set a 30-second timer to make the game faster and more competitive.

title: Dictionary Race
desc: The teacher reads dictionary definitions of words starting with a specific letter, and teams race to guess the word.
steps: Divide the class into 3 or 4 teams.
Choose a page from a monolingual dictionary and tell students the starting letter.
Read the definition of a word.
Students shout out the word they think is being defined.
variation: Have students take turns finding a word and reading the definition to the class instead of the teacher.

title: Hangman Expanded
desc: Classic hangman game with an added layer of providing descriptive clues about the word.
steps: Place the number of blanks for a word on the board.
Provide clues about the word's appearance, duties, or accessories.
Students guess letters to reveal the word.
Discuss the meaning of the word once revealed.
variation: Use specific categories like occupations, locations, or animals for focused vocabulary review.

title: Chain of Words
desc: A fast-paced chain where each new word must begin with the last letter of the previous word.
steps: The teacher starts by saying or reading a word.
Students join in by supplying a new word that begins with the last letter of the previous word.
Maintain a fast pace to keep energy high.
variation: Restrict the words to a specific category (e.g., 'Food' or 'Verbs') for a harder challenge, or have students throw a soft ball to choose the next speaker instead of going in a circle.

title: Toilet Paper Ice-Breaker
desc: Students tear off sheets of toilet paper and must share one fact about themselves for each sheet they took.
steps: Pass around a roll of toilet paper and tell students to tear off some squares without explaining why.
Once everyone has their paper, explain the rules.
Every person must say as many sentences about themselves as the number of squares they have.
The teacher should introduce themselves first to show the example.
variation: Have other students formulate follow-up questions for every fact shared.

title: Everyday Words
desc: Students guess everyday objects based on words or phrases typically printed on them.
steps: Write a phrase commonly found on an object on the board (e.g., 'CRUSH-PROOF PACK' or 'TWIST ON/OFF').
Have the class guess the object the phrase is written on (e.g., cigarette packet, jam jar).
Continue with other everyday phrases like 'BACK SPACE' or 'THANK YOU'.
variation: Have students bring in their own examples of everyday text to test the teacher and class.

title: Noughts and Crosses
desc: A tic-tac-toe game where teams must successfully answer a category-based question to claim a square.
steps: Draw a 3x3 grid on the board.
Assign a category to each of the 9 squares (e.g., Animals, Food, Sport, Countries).
Divide the class into Team O and Team X.
Teams choose a square and must provide a correct answer or sentence fitting the category to claim it.
variation: Do not allow repetition of any words previously used during the game.

title: Act It Out
desc: Students write a short script based on a specific scenario and act it out for the class.
steps: Hand out plot scenarios to groups (e.g., 'A detective interviews witnesses to a bizarre noise').
Give groups 10 minutes to write a short script based on the prompt.
Have each group act out their scene for the rest of the class.
Encourage the use of target grammar, such as the past simple tense.
variation: Give them a scenario where they must resolve a conflict, like a neighbor complaining about a loud party.

title: The Balloon Debate
desc: Students take on the persona of a famous figure and debate why they should survive in a sinking hot air balloon.
steps: Assign or let students choose the identity of a famous historical or pop culture figure.
Set the scene: They are all in a hot air balloon that is losing altitude, and one person must be thrown out.
Each student must present a persuasive argument for why their character is too important to be thrown out.
The class votes on who is eliminated each round.
variation: Use professions instead of famous people (e.g., Doctor, Teacher, Artist, Engineer).

title: Casino
desc: A grammar game where groups bet points on their ability to correctly identify and fix sentence errors.
steps: Hand out a list of sentences containing one or two errors.
Allot 100 points to each group.
Groups bet a number of points (maximum 10) that they can correct the error in a specific sentence.
Add points for correct answers and subtract points for incorrect ones.
variation: Allow teams to challenge another team's correction to steal their bet.

title: Puzzle Stories
desc: Students use yes/no questions to solve lateral thinking riddles.
steps: Read a short puzzle scenario to the class (e.g., 'A man walked into a bar and asked for water. The barman pointed a gun at him. The man said thank you and left.').
Students must ask yes/no questions to figure out the context.
Continue until they solve the puzzle (e.g., 'He had the hiccups').
variation: Have students bring in their own lateral thinking puzzles to test the teacher and classmates.

title: Story Revision
desc: Students reconstruct a sentence word by word, with each student repeating from the very beginning.
steps: Cut a story sentence into individual words and hand them out to students in the correct order.
Student 1 reads their word.
Student 2 reads Student 1's word, then their own.
Student 3 reads Student 1 and 2's words, then their own, and so on.
variation: Use this technique to practice days of the week or months of the year with lower levels, pointing at students randomly.

title: Repetitive Questions
desc: A rapid-fire drill where students must provide a unique answer to the same repetitive question.
steps: Ask a simple question to a student, such as 'What did you do yesterday?'.
The student answers quickly.
Immediately ask the next student the exact same question.
Each student must provide a completely new and unique answer without hesitating.
variation: Change the target grammar structure rapidly (e.g., shift from 'What did you...' to 'Where will you...').

title: Back to the Board
desc: A student faces away from the board and guesses a hidden word based on English clues from classmates.
steps: Have one student volunteer sit in a chair facing away from the whiteboard.
Write a word on the board (or stick a post-it note on their back).
The rest of the class gives clues in English without saying the target word.
The volunteer must guess the word.
variation: Put two students in chairs facing the class and make it a race to see who can guess their word first based on their team's clues.

title: The Hot Seat
desc: One student sits facing the class. Their team must describe a hidden word written on the board behind them.
steps: Divide the class into two teams.
Place a chair at the front facing the class (the 'Hot Seat').
A volunteer from Team A sits in the chair.
Write a target vocabulary word on the board directly behind the student.
Team A has 60 seconds to describe the word to their teammate without using the word itself, spelling it, or translating it.
If the student guesses correctly, they get a point. Swap teams and repeat.
variation: For advanced students, allow the opposing team to make distracting noises, or use idioms instead of single vocabulary words.

title: Find Someone Who
desc: Students mingle and ask yes/no questions to find classmates who match specific criteria on their worksheet.
steps: Distribute a 'Find Someone Who' grid to each student (e.g., 'Find someone who likes spicy food').
Students stand up and mingle around the classroom.
They must ask questions in English to find a match (e.g., 'Do you like spicy food?').
If a classmate answers 'Yes', the student writes their name in the grid box.
The first person to fill their entire sheet yells 'Finished!'.
variation: Require students to ask a follow-up 'Wh-' question (e.g., 'What is your favorite spicy food?') when they get a 'Yes' answer to extend the conversation.

title: Alphabet Race
desc: A fast-paced relay where teams race to write a word for every letter of the alphabet on the board.
steps: Divide the whiteboard into columns for each team.
Write the alphabet vertically down the side of each column.
Divide the class into teams and give one marker to the first student in each line.
On 'Go', the first student runs to the board, writes a word starting with any available letter, and runs back.
They pass the marker to the next student. The first team to complete the entire alphabet wins.
variation: Restrict the words to a specific lesson theme (e.g., only adjectives, or only things found in a kitchen) to increase the difficulty.

title: Would You Rather
desc: Students are presented with two difficult choices and must select one, thoroughly explaining their reasoning.
steps: Write or project a 'Would you rather' dilemma on the board (e.g., 'Would you rather be able to fly or be invisible?').
Give students 1 minute of silence to think about their choice and formulate a reason.
Have students discuss and defend their answers in pairs.
Ask a few students to share their partner's answer and reasoning with the whole class to check listening comprehension.
variation: Have students write their own 'Would you rather' questions on scrap paper, put them in a hat, and draw them randomly for the class to discuss.

title: Action Simon Says
desc: A classic listening game where students must only perform physical actions if preceded by the target phrase.
steps: Stand at the front of the class and give an imperative instruction (e.g., 'Simon says touch your nose').
Students must immediately perform the action.
Give an instruction without saying 'Simon says' first (e.g., 'Jump!').
Students must stay completely still. Anyone who performs the action is 'out' and must sit down.
The last student standing wins.
variation: Instead of eliminating students (which can cause disengagement), have 'out' students do three star jumps before rejoining the game.

title: Pictionary Relay
desc: A team-based drawing relay where students quickly sketch vocabulary words for their teammates to guess.
steps: Divide the class into two teams. Have them line up facing the whiteboard.
Show the first student in each line the same secret vocabulary word.
On 'Go', they run to the board and start drawing the word without speaking or writing letters.
The first team to correctly shout out the word gets a point.
The drawers go to the back of the line, and the next two students step up for a new word.
variation: For older teens, blindfold the person drawing and have a teammate guide their hand using only English directions (e.g., 'Up', 'Left', 'Draw a circle').

title: Similarities
desc: Students ask each other questions to find three non-obvious things they have in common.
steps: Explain that students must find three things they have in common with a partner.
The similarities must not be obvious (e.g., they cannot use 'we both have black hair').
Model the activity by having the class interview you until they find three non-obvious similarities.
Have students mingle or work in pairs to find their similarities.
variation: For advanced classes, require them to find similarities based on abstract topics like fears, childhood memories, or future goals.

title: The Diminishing Sentence
desc: Students build a long sentence together, then try to recite it as words are randomly erased one by one.
steps: Write a basic sentence on the board.
Have students add one word at a time to make the sentence as long and descriptive as possible.
Read the full sentence together.
Erase one random word from the board and have the class read the full sentence again, including the missing word.
Continue erasing words randomly until the board is almost blank, relying entirely on the students' memory to recite it.
variation: Start the next class with only the final word left on the board and see if the class can reconstruct the entire paragraph from memory.

title: Reported Speech Chain
desc: Students introduce themselves and state a fact, and the next student must report it to the class before introducing themselves.
steps: Student A announces their name and a personal fact (e.g., 'My name is George and I like playing chess.').
Student B reports Student A's statement to the class using reported speech (e.g., 'She said she was X and that she liked X.').
Student B then introduces themselves and states a new fact.
Student C reports Student B's fact, then introduces themselves.
Continue the chain around the room.
variation: To increase the challenge, have the final student try to recount the reported speech for the last 5 students in a row.

title: Grammar Treasure Hunt
desc: Students follow written clues hidden around the room or school to collect words that form a complete sentence.
steps: Write a 7-word sentence and write each word on a separate piece of paper.
Pin or hide the words in different locations around the classroom or school.
On each piece of paper, write instructions on how to find the next piece (e.g., 'Go upstairs, turn right and look beside the fourth door on the left.').
Give the first clue to the groups.
Once a group collects all the words, they must arrange them into the correct grammatical order to win.
variation: Instead of words forming a sentence, the hidden papers can be puzzle pieces or grammar questions they must answer before getting the next clue.

title: Verbal Charades
desc: Students draw a word from a hat and must describe it to the class without saying the word or using hand motions.
steps: Write target vocabulary nouns on individual slips of paper.
Put all the slips of paper into a hat or container.
A student volunteers to draw one slip of paper without showing it.
They must describe the word to the class using only English, without saying the actual word or using physical gestures.
The rest of the class shouts out their guesses until someone gets it right.
variation: Add a rule that descriptive noises are banned to force students to use more complex vocabulary.

title: Yes/No Taboo
desc: Students engage in conversation and try to trick their partner into saying the forbidden words 'Yes' or 'No'.
steps: Divide the class into pairs.
Explain that the words 'Yes' and 'No' (and their variations like 'Yeah' or 'Nope') are strictly taboo.
Students take turns asking each other rapid-fire questions designed to trick the other person into answering with a yes or no.
If a student says a taboo word, their partner gets a point.
Encourage students to elaborate and use full sentences to avoid the trap.
variation: Add 'Black' and 'White' to the list of taboo words to make answering descriptive questions much harder.

title: Word Associations
desc: Students are given two unrelated words and must connect them through a chain of associated vocabulary.
steps: Write two completely unrelated words on the board (e.g., 'Bread' and 'Baby').
Put students into pairs.
Teams must write a chain of words that logically links the first word to the second.
For example: Bread -> Food -> Drink -> Milk -> Baby.
The pair that connects the words using the fewest possible steps wins the round.
variation: Play this out loud as a whole class circle game where each student says the first word that comes to mind based on the previous person's word.

title: 3-Part Sentences
desc: Students draw random grammar constraints from boxes and must instantly form a correct sentence using a given verb.
steps: Label three boxes: 'Tense', 'Pronouns', and 'Positive/Negative'.
Fill each box with corresponding slips of paper.
Call a student to the front to draw one slip from each of the three boxes.
Shout out an infinitive verb (e.g., 'To Eat').
The student must immediately formulate a correct sentence using the verb and the three constraints.
variation: Have the rest of the class write down the correct sentence in their notebooks simultaneously to practice written grammar alongside the oral practice.

title: Name As Many
desc: Students compete to name as many items as possible within a specific, challenging category.
steps: Divide the class into teams.
Read aloud or hand out a specific category card (e.g., 'Name 5 body parts above the neck with 3 letters' or 'Name the continents in alphabetical order').
Give students a set time limit (e.g., 60 seconds) to brainstorm and write down their answers.
The team with the most correct words wins the round.
variation: For lower levels, allow the use of dictionaries or expand the categories to be much broader.

title: Word Explosion
desc: Students brainstorm and write as many English words as they can on the board to build confidence.
steps: Put students into small groups and have them list all the English words they can think of on a piece of paper.
Have groups send representatives to the board to write their words simultaneously.
The goal is to cover the entire board in a mass of English words.
Once the board is full, challenge groups to make the longest possible sentence using only the words on the board.
variation: Restrict the words to a specific grammatical category (e.g., only action verbs or only uncountable nouns).

title: Imagine a Photo
desc: Students mentally select significant personal photos and describe them to the class, prompting follow-up questions.
steps: Ask students to imagine they have brought 4 of their favorite personal photos to class.
Give them a few minutes to think about the people, places, or events in these imaginary photos.
Students take turns describing one of their photos in detail to the class or a partner.
The audience must ask follow-up questions to find out more information about the photo's context.
variation: Have the listening partner try to quickly sketch the photo on scrap paper based purely on the speaker's description.

title: Blind Drawing: Places
desc: One student describes their home in meticulous detail while their partner attempts to draw an accurate floor plan.
steps: Divide the class into pairs: Student A (Speaker) and Student B (Drawer).
Student A imagines their house and must describe it in detail to Student B, as if describing it to a blind person.
Student B draws the floor plan or room exactly as described, without speaking.
Once finished, they compare the drawing to the speaker's actual house layout to see where communication broke down.
Swap roles and repeat.
variation: Have students describe a famous landmark, a fantasy castle, or their dream bedroom instead of their own home.

title: Jumbled Story
desc: Each student receives one sentence of a story and must mingle to put the narrative in the correct chronological order.
steps: Find a short, sequential story and cut it up so that each sentence is on a separate slip of paper.
Distribute one sentence to each student in the class.
Students must read their sentences out loud to each other and listen carefully to their classmates.
Without showing their papers, the class must physically arrange themselves in a line corresponding to the correct chronological order of the story.
Once they believe they are in order, they read the story aloud from start to finish to check.
variation: For smaller classes, give each student 2-3 sentences, or use the steps of a recipe instead of a narrative story.
